text:
(1) Williamsburg Bridge taken from Manhattan; looking southeastward at Brooklyn. The tug boat "El chico and the oil barge Sunoco 3", are seen passing north under the bridge.

September 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The Brooklyn shore line at the Williamsburg Bridge, as seen from East 3rd Street Dock, in Manhattan. The yacht "North Star" is also seen in the foreground.

June 10, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, showing the Dredge Barge "Governor Wafield".

September 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Bridges - Williamsburg Bridge [spans the East River, beginning at Delancey Street in Manhattan and terminating in Williamsburg, Brooklyn - View of the Bridge, showing Tugboat El Chico; Oil barge Sunoco 3; Yacht North Star; Dredge barge.]

text:
(1) Realistic advertising in the form of a movable replica. This sign is on a roof, at about Madison Street, as seen from Manhattan Bridge.

April 3, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) Space on a billboard, donated to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, in its campaign for funds; seen on Delancey Street, from the Williamsburg Bridge.

September 18, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same as No. 1.

June 26, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Advertisements - Advertising signs and billboards.

text:
(1) The Williamsburg Bridge spans the East River; beginning at Delancey Street, in Manhattan, and terminating in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The view taken from East 5th Street Dock, looking southeastward. June 10, 1933. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same; as seen from dock at foot of Stanton Street, in Manhattan, looking toward Brooklyn. June 10, 1933. P. L. Sperr.
title: Bridges - Williamsburg Bridge [spans the East River, beginning at Delancey Street in Manhattan and terminating in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.]

text:
(1) The Williamsburg Bridge spans the East River; beginning at Delancey Street, in Manhattan, and terminating in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The view taken from East 5th Street Dock, looking southeastward. June 10, 1933. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same; as seen from dock at foot of Stanton Street, in Manhattan, looking toward Brooklyn. June 10, 1933. P. L. Sperr.
title: Bridges - Williamsburg Bridge [spans the East River, beginning at Delancey Street in Manhattan and terminating in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.]

text:
(1) Clinton Street, east side, north from, but not including Delancey Street. Shown at No. 96-90 is the Grand Central Palace. Further northward at No. 82-80 is the Clinton Theatre.

March 19, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A further view northward from the Clinton Theatre, which is south of Rivington Street.

April 1, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

Neg.* 2552

(1) Clinton Street, east side, north from, but not including Delancey Street. Shown at No. 96-90 is the Grand Central Palace. Further northward at No. 82-80 is the Clinton Theatre.

March 19, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A further view northward from the Clinton Theatre, which is south of Rivington Street.

April 1, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

Neg.* 2552

Delancey Street, north side, west from Clinton to Norfolk Streets. Loew's Delancey Theatre, is at the N.W. corner of Suffolk Street.

February 12, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

The 6-story structure partially shown on the right is to be replaced by a 1-story business building according to the Times of May 3, 1938. This bears Nos. 156-164 Delancey Street and No. 107½ Clinton Street; being at the N.W. corner of same.

East River Drive, south from East 11th Street. The piles of rock and sand shown on the left will be used to fill in the shoreline at this point. Across same, in the background is the Williamsburg Bridge, connecting Delancey Street, Manhattan with Brooklyn. No. 2 of this set is in the same direction from East 5th Street.

June 15, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

East River Drive, south from East 11th Street. The piles of rock and sand shown on the left will be used to fill in the shoreline at this point. Across same, in the background is the Williamsburg Bridge, connecting Delancey Street, Manhattan with Brooklyn. No. 2 of this set is in the same direction from East 5th Street.

June 15, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Bridges - Williamsburg Bridge [spans the East River, beginning at Delancey Street in Manhattan and terminating in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.]
